Block 31 Gas Plant Risk Management Plan:

                      Executive Summary



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



The  Block  31 gas plant is committed to worker  and  public

safety.  This  commitment is demonstrated by  the  resources

invested  in accident prevention, such as training personnel

and   considering   safety  in  the  design,   installation,

operation,  and maintenance of our processes. This  facility

was  designed  and constructed utilizing generally  accepted

industry codes and recommended practices such as ANSI,  ASME

and  API.   It  is  our policy to adhere to  all  applicable

federal,  state, and local laws. Our policy is to  implement

reasonable  controls  to  prevent  foreseeable  releases  of

regulated  substances.  However, if a  release  does  occur,

plans  have  been  developed  to  control  and  contain  the

release.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED

SUBSTANCES



The  Block 31 gas plant is located west of Crane, Texas. The

plant  has  several regulated flammables, such  as  methane,

ethane, propane, butanes and pentanes.



The  Block 31 plant handles gas produced from the  Block  31

field.   Produced  gas is processed to  remove  natural  gas

liquids  (NGLs),  then  reinjected into  the  reservoir  for

pressure maintenance, used for fuel, or sold.



Gas  comes into the plant at pressures ranging from 10  psig

to  1200  psig.   Gas must be at 1200 psig  for  processing;

therefore,  compression is required for streams coming  into

the  plant  at lower pressures.  Any liquid that  drops  out

from the gas during compression is returned to the field and

combined with the oil production.



After  inlet compression, the gas is split into two streams.

Part  of the gas flows straight to injection, and part flows

to the Nitrogen Rejection Facility (NRF) for processing.



Injection Gas

  Triethylene glycol is injected into this stream to prevent

hydrate  formation

then    is compressed and  injected  into

the reservoir.



The  glycol/water  mixture is separated in the  glycol/water

coalescer separator.  The rich glycol is regenerated to lean

glycol  in  the glycol reboiler, which is heated  by  steam.

Lean glycol flows to the surge tank and is injected into the

feed gas again.  The water vapor and a small amount of light

hydrocarbon driven off in the reboiler.





Nitrogen Rejection Facility (NRF)

Diglycolamine  (DGA) is used to sweeten, or remove  CO2  and

H2S  from, the gas stream that flows through the  NRF.   The

rich  DGA  is regenerated by reducing the pressure and  then

heating the amine to remove any light hydrocarbons, CO2, and

H2S.   Steam provides the heat needed for this regeneration.

The  hydrocarbon gases driven off are returned to the  plant

inlet gas system.  The acid gases CO2 and H2S are compressed

and  injected.  The lean DGA returns to the amine  contactor

to sweeten more gas.



NRF   feed   gas   is   dehydrated  after  the   sweetening.

Triethylene glycol absorbs water and a small amount of light

hydrocarbon  from the gas.  After contacting  the  gas,  the

rich  glycol  is  heated and flows into a flash  tank  where

light  hydrocarbons vaporize.  These light hydrocarbons  are

returned  to  the plant inlet system.  Water  and  remaining

hydrocarbon gases are removed from the glycol in the  glycol

reboiler,   which  is  heated  by  steam.   The  water   and

hydrocarbon  vent  gases  are released  to  the  atmosphere.

Plans  are  underway  to  condense these  gases  to  recover

liquids  and  return the remaining vapor back to  our  inlet

system.  The lean glycol returns to the glycol contactors to

continue the process.



The  gas  must  be free of all water, CO2,  and  H2S  before

entering the cryogenic process.  Mol sieve beds are used  to

remove  any remaining water, CO2, and H2S.  Two beds are  in

service  while  two  beds are being  regenerated.  Beds  are

regenerated

using heated nitrogen that flows countercurrent

to  the  process  flow. Regeneration gas is cooled  and  re-

injected into the reservoir.  Regeneration gas heaters  burn

sweet residue gas.



The  sweetened, dehydrated gas flows through  the  cryogenic

process for removal of ethane and heavier hydrocarbons.  The

gas is chilled to very low temperatures using a single stage

turbo expansion process.  The liquids removed are stored  in

pressurized tanks and pumped into pipelines for sales.



The  remaining  gas  is a mixture of methane  and  nitrogen.

These  are  separated  in  the  nitrogen  rejection  unit(s)

(NRU's).  The NRU's chill the gas to condense  methane  from

nitrogen.   The  nitrogen is vented  or  injected,  and  the

methane is vaporized and used for plant fuel or sold.



Auxiliary Systems

Steam is the heat source for many units at Block 31.   Steam

is  produced  in  two  boilers.  Each boiler  by  itself  is

capable    of    producing   the   entire   plant's    steam

requirements.Both are operated in the event an upset  occurs

with  one,  there is no downtime in getting steam  from  the

other unit.  The boilers burn sweet residue gas.



The  flare  at  Block 31 is used for upsets and  maintenance

events.   Other than a pilot stream, no gas is flared  under

normal operations.  The pilot stream is sweet residue gas.



An  open  drain system in the plant carries fluids to  sumps

scattered throughout the plant.  From the sumps, the  fluids

are  pumped into five pits.  Oil collected in these pits  is

routed to the slop oil pit, then to the slop oil tank,  then

pumped to the oil production facility.  Water ends up in the

largest pit before injection into a disposal well.





OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS



The worst case scenarios (WCS) associated with a release  of

flammable  substances  at the gas plant  is  a  vapor  cloud

explosion (VCE) involving the full inventory of the  largest

pressure  vessel containing a fla

mmable mixture  of  natural

gas  liquids.  The maximum expected liquid  inventory  of  a

34,000  gallon pressure vessel, was assumed to  release  and

ignite,  resulting  in  a VCE. According  to  EPA's  look-up

tables  the maximum distance to the 1-psi endpoint for  this

WCS  is  0.39  mile. Since this facility  is  located  in  a

relatively remote, unoccupied area, the worst-case  scenario

would not reach a public receptor. Although we have numerous

controls  to  prevent  such releases  and  to  manage  their

consequences, no credit for passive mitigation measures  was

taken into account in evaluating this WCS.



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

This  facility complies with EPA's accident prevention  rule

and  all  applicable  Federal, state  and  local  codes  and

regulations.  This facility has training programs  in  place

for its personnel and a comprehensive maintenance program to

ensure  that the equipment is maintained properly to  reduce

the  possibility of a release of flammable liquids or gases.

A  management of change policy is established that  requires

all  facility  modifications to be reviewed by  engineering,

operations and safety departments to promote the  safety  of

the employees and public.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The  Block 31 gas plant has an excellent record of  accident

prevention over the past 5 years. This facility has not  had

an  accident  involving  release of  any  of  the  regulated

flammables   that  caused  deaths,  injuries,  property   or

environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings  in  place

during the past 5 years.



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

In the event of an emergency involving our facility, it is

our policy to notify the Crane County Sheriff and Fire

Departments and request that they respond to the emergency.

We have discussed this policy with these departments;

members of these  departments have inspected our facility.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

None.
